metadata.title: CASE 218/04: Allegation of Possible Bribery at Pristina Airport
metadata.primary_source: United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo

overview: This document details the ongoing investigation into alleged bribery involving UNMIK at Pristina Airport. The inquiry was prompted by a Divisional Manager's report of a €5200 bribe linked to a procurement contract, with the funds yet unfound.

applicable_laws.excerpt: This case concerns an allegation of attempted bribery and corruption as cited in Article 344 of the Provisional Criminal Code of Kosovo.

methodology.description: Conducted under Executive Decision No 2003/16, the investigation involved interviews with key personnel and a comprehensive review of relevant documents.
interviews: Two current Border Boundary Police investigators
Regional Crime Squad Pristina Region officials
documents_reviewed: Letter from the Divisional Manager to the UNMIK Police Officer, dated 2002-10-11
File note from the PEAP Official, dated 2002-10-08

background.context: In October 2002, an envelope allegedly containing €5200 was left at the PEAP office after a meeting about a procurement contract. The funds remain untraced, and efforts to locate the police report are ongoing.
timeline: 2002-09-15;2002-09-30: Divisional Manager away from the Airport
2002-10-04: Meeting in the PEAP Official's office
2002-09-27;2004-09-27: Letter sent to UNMIK Police Officer 2 regarding investigation status

allegations.description: An envelope containing €5200 was reportedly left in a PEAP office, possibly linked to a procurement contract.
allegations.findings: The €5200 is not a typical round sum. The company identified as 'escavator' corresponds with Company 1, which secured the car park contract.

allegations.description: A former Engineer accused the PEAP Official of accepting documents post-bid closure.
The missing €5200 is still being investigated with no trace found.
allegations.findings: Extensive enquiries by current Border Boundary Police were fruitless in tracing the police report or the money.

findings: Evidence suggests a corrupt payment attempt targeting the PEAP Official occurred in October 2002.
Identity or motive behind the payment remains unidentified.
The UNMIK police's investigation, started over two years ago, continues.
The ITF case is closed to avoid hindering the judicial process.

violations.excerpt: Possible violation due to attempted bribery and corruption.

actions: Enhance monitoring of procurement processes at Pristina Airport.
Implement stricter compliance controls for bid submissions.
Establish a robust follow-up system to promptly track any financial irregularities.
